2008 Virginia Fire Incident Reporting Sy: Quick Facts
Somewhere in Virginia, every minute, an incident occurs in which a fire department
responds - Fire departments responded to an average of 1,697 incidents per day in 2008.
(1,082 EMS responses, 81 fire responses and 535 other responses each day.)
The demand for fire service has expanded; fire service does more than put out fires
- 64% of the incidents were rescue and EMS calls; 10% were good intent calls; 9% were
false alarms, 7% were service calls, 5% were fires, 5% were hazardous condition calls,
and 1% were other calls.
Fire service saved property from being destroyed and reduced the amount of
property damage - 6.4 billion dollars of property and contents were saved with fire
incidents in 2008; the total dollar loss associated with fires was $325 million dollars.
Civilian injuries and deaths from fires happen more than you expect - On average,
every 16 hours, a civilian was hurt or died as a result of a fire; there were a total of 554
civilian fire casualties (474 injuries and 80 deaths) that occurred in 2008.
Firefighters are exposed to hazardous situations - Fire service suffered 335 injuries
and 1 death while responding to incidents.
Fire departments extinguished more than just home fires - Structure fires accounted
for 34% of the fire incidents, while brush or natural vegetation fires made up 29% of the
total fires.
Fire service personnel committed long hours to control emergency situations - Fire
service accumulated a total of 3,010,356 man hours responding to, controlling and
clearing incidents in 2008.
Cooking in the home was the leading cause of fires - 31% of the residential structure
fires were due to cooking; the fires accounted for 126 civilian injuries.
Emergency situations impact everyone in Virginia - Incidents occurred at a rate of
92.3 incidents for every 1,000 Virginia residents in 2008.
